nodes.bodyText:
Let's please only store this in milliseconds.
I would do the conversion external to the SyncProcessor entirely. I'd convert to milliseconds immediately after reading config file, before exiting the config builder. Or, immediately after receiving a user-provided value from the Java builder, and before exiting the config builder.
(Point in short, the unit conversion is an aspect of configuration logic, not of sync processor logic.)
I'll get this updated.
Is this still optimally worded, given the renaming?

+/**
+ * Handles conflicts between models observed during model synchronization in the DataStore.
+ * Such conflicts may arise between version of models kept locally, and competing versions
+ * found in the remote AppSync system.
+ */
+public interface DataStoreConflictHandler {
+    /**
+     * Resolves a DataStore conflict.
+     * @param conflictData Data about the conflict.
+     * @param onResult A callback that should be invoked when the conflict handling is complete.
+     * @param <T> The type of model for which a conflict was observed
+     */
+    <T extends Model> void resolveConflict(

nodes.bodyText:
So I think we have a couple of options:


Current implementation Allow the implementation classes to handle the error in whatever manner they see appropriate. ApplyRemoteConflictHandler for example, does this by making the user provide an instance of an DataStoreErrorHandler in the constructor.


Alternative 1 add a Consumer<Throwable> as a third parameter


Alternative 2 add a DataStoreErrorHandler as a third parameter. This would force any implementation of DataStoreConflictHandler to use an error handler.


Thoughts?

nodes.bodyText:
Hmm. Maybe @drochetti thought about this one. If so / if not, maybe we should pow-wow with him for 15 minutes later today to discuss this specific topic?
We can also do a variant of #2, where-in we try/catch the conflict handler, and then dispatch any exception to the datastore handler. The user would continue to provide the same handler that they do now. And we would enforce the policy of falling back to the error handler, in an internal final class that the user couldn't get at.

nodes.bodyText: Shouldn't need this if. In the case that syncPageSize == DEFAULT_SYNC_PAGE_SIZE, you'd just set the value to the same thing again. Which wouldn't change the system behavior.
See above
Same, shouldn't need the if.
See above

Yikes...missed that one. The method has been renamed.
Regarding the if statements, see my response in line 90 of DataStoreConfiguration.java.
We can definitely revisit this, but it will be dependent on what we decide with regards to making the scalar values nullable. This is basically a mechanism for us to determine the intent of the developer by assuming that they only want to override anything if a non-default value is passed.
Okay cool I understand the intent now! Thanks
My latest commit makes the scalar values nullable and returns defaults from the getters if the underlying field is null

I don't think you ever use the fact that these are objects. (They have non-null default values, and you overwrite the m via primitive types.)
So, I think it should be both safe and preferable to store these as their primitive counterparsts,long and int .
I toyed around with the idea of making these nullable, but forgot to change these declarations back
Since this one is user-exposed, I think we want this work in minutes, here. Inside the builder, convert to ms.
Done.
Hm, how does this  work? Doesn't the user config always clobber the file config?

It would, it it wasn't for those "check for default value" if statement in the setters. Basically, the logic is as follows:

Create a builder using the settings from amplifyconfiguration.json. (builder(pluginJson))
Then call the setters for each of the properties of the builder by passing in the corresponding value from userProvidedConfiguration.

This results in any non-default values provided in userProvidedConfiguration to override whatever was in the JSON, which I believe is the behavior we were looking for.
The other option I considered was to make the scalar values in the configuration object nullable. We would then only override using non-null values from userProvidedConfiguration. This in turn, added some complexity where I'd have to create a config object without default values and then pass the burden of checking whether or not they were null down to the wherever the settings are actually read.
Let me know if this makes sense.

That actually worked, so I updated the code to make the fields null (with the exception of the handler) to start with and then I only write to them if the underlying field is null. The getters, in turn, return a default value if the underlying field is null

Changes made in the latest commit

Removed the logic from the getters and modified the builder's build method to ensure defaults when instructed to do so.
You can probably strip this off now that it's being referenced at least from test
Done
Are these default values the same on iOS and JavaScript? I don't remember, but I may have just made these up on the fly.
I was missing a 0 from DEFAULT_SYNC_MAX_RECORDS...iOS is using 10_000

Can we push this null check down into the builder(...) so that we don't have to process it in this block here in the plugin? That is,
dataStoreConfiguration = DataStoreConfiguration.builder(configFromDisk, null).build();
That's easy enough to do. I was debating doing that, but decided against pushing that logic to the builder. In hindsight, it's the right place for it.

I guess there are two ways of looking at this:

The current view:


The orchestrator is an optional component. It's presence is determined by the content of the configuration. If the configuration does not permit remote sync, then don't create an orchestrator.


The original view:


The orchestrator is a data store component, it is constructed at the same time as the plugin. Later, if the configuration determines that sync should be enabled, the orchestrator is started.

Realistically, the only concrete concern is whether or not orchestrator is null at the time you call start. So long as configuration is definitely done by the time initialize() rolls around, you should be good.

After going back through, I went with a version that's more closely aligned with the original view. I have a pluginConfiguration class variable in the Orchestrator ' and also pass a reference to that in to the SyncEngine (where it's actually used). That variable gets initialized in the configure method of the Orchestrator, so by the time the SyncEngine needs it, it will should be set.

I'd expect that dataStoreConfiguration would be guaranteed non-null, here. That is, if there's no config file, and the user supplies no config, then you still have some system defaults you can use. Right? So, those could go into a non-null dataStoreConfiguration. And that would have a different effect here.
The current logic says basically "never do a delta sync."
But that's not what we want -- we want a delta sync if the last sync time is within some san default (1 day? Whatever it is?)
In other words, I'd prefer to have an Objects.requireNonNull(...) and @NonNull directive on the SyncProcessor constructor, and then just never have to worry about this branch, in this spot.
Yeah. I added this here to prevent a potential NPE, but by the time it gets here, we’re sure to have at least default values.

Changes made in the latest commit
I created a provider interface that I'm now passing from the the plugin down to the Orchestrator and SyncProcessors. By the time these classes invoke the provider method to get the configuration, the plugin will have already setup the configuration in the configure method.

This is still a little spooky. If do:
builder.syncMaxRecords(1000)
    .syncMaxRecords(500)
    .build();

The value is 1000 even though I'd probably expect it to be 500...
(Same for others with this pattern.)

Yeah...i agree, it feels wonky. I’ll review this tomorrow just to make sure. The struggle here is trying to come up with a mechanism that we can use to determine which values have precedence over the other. I would imagine we want to create the object with defaults, then read from file, then use anything passed in by the user.
I’ll take another look at it tomorrow.

Can you put this construction stuff in the build() so that the DataStoreConfiguration doesn't have any logic, it just returned a single, final, stored instance value?
(Same for others with this pattern.)

Changes made in the latest commit
With the latest commit, the following rules should apply:

Read settings from config file (if any)
Read settings from user-provided POJO (if any). Apply any non-null values
Fill in any missing fields with default values if instructed to do so (More on that below)

Changes to DataStoreConfiguration.Builder

Moved most of the logic out of the DataStoreConfiguration methods
Added a constructor that takes an instance of DataStoreConfiguration as the user-provided settings in addition to the JSON values
Added a field to the Builder called ensureDefaults. This field is only set to true if the new constructor is called.
Modified build() method to populate defaults if  ensureDefaults is true

Changes to DataStoreConfiguration

Marked two builder methods(builder(JSONObject), and builder(JSONObject, DataStoreConfiguration)) as package private so they should only be callable internally. This leaves the parameter-less builder() method as the only option when user's want to create an instance of DataStoreConfiguration to pass in overrides. When created via this method, the builder's build() method will leave any scalar fields not explicitly set by the user as null.
Simplified getters and added a new getter for getSyncIntervalInMinutes
You actually use it to model a few things right, it is no longer just user-provided?

Should this also include our opinionated error and conflict handlers?
Those get set in the default constructor of the builder since there's no ambiguity with those two fields. That being said, it doesn't hurt to be explicit about it and setting it here.
